argument: Muslims prevent people from eating during Ramadan.
counter-argument: Muslims do not prevent people from eating during Ramadan, but rather, Muslims themselves fast from dawn to sunset during the month of Ramadan as a religious obligation, while non-Muslims are free to eat and drink as they normally would. In fact, many Muslim-majority countries make accommodations for non-Muslims during Ramadan, such as keeping restaurants and cafes open during the day. Additionally, Muslims often invite non-Muslim friends and colleagues to break their fast with them after sunset, promoting unity and community.
